name: Vaidyanath

deity.mythology_link: Where Ravana worshipped Shiva and the Lord became the Supreme Healer

location.sacred_geography: Located in the Santhal Parganas region, the temple complex houses 21 other temples. The Kanwar Yatra, one of the world's largest religious gatherings, culminates here.
location.access: 350 km from Kolkata, 280 km from Patna, connected by Baidyanath Dham railway station

significance.rank: Ninth Jyotirlinga, supreme healing shrine, endpoint of massive Kanwar Yatra
significance.philosophy: Vaidyanath represents Shiva as the Divine Healer. Here, Shiva cured even his enemy Ravana. This teaches that divine grace extends to all who sincerely worship—regardless of their nature. The Lord's healing power transcends moral judgment.

stats.unique_feature: Endpoint of world's largest annual pilgrimage (Kanwar Yatra)

description: Baba Baidyanath is worshipped as the Supreme Physician—the deity who heals all ailments, physical and spiritual. The temple's extraordinary legend involves Ravana, the demon king of Lanka, who performed such intense penance here that Shiva was compelled to grant him a boon. When Ravana's arms were injured during his austerities, Shiva himself healed them, earning the name Vaidyanath (Lord of Physicians). The temple complex contains 22 shrines, and the main lingam is said to have been installed by Ravana himself. Every year during Shravan month, over 20 million Kanwariyas walk hundreds of kilometers carrying sacred Ganga water to offer here—making this one of the largest annual religious gatherings on Earth. The healing energy here is palpable; countless devotees report miraculous cures.
secret_hook: Why did Shiva heal Ravana, his future enemy? Some scholars believe the Lord already knew Ravana's destiny—and that the demon's devotion here was so pure that it transcended his future sins. Can genuine devotion override karma?
